38770782.review:
[u][h1] It's Like I'm 6 Again[/h1][/u]

I first got this game in August of 1999.
It was my 6th birthday, and my father picked this up for me as a birthday gift. Now, some might question why a 6 year old kid should get this as a game to play, but the simple answer to that is that my father also wanted to turn some dinos into chunky kibble. I remember running around the first level in a mix of fear and excitement, terror and curiosity. I hadn't the slightest clue what I was doing or what I even needed to do, but that didn't stop me. To the beat of that awesome original N64 soundtrack, I sliced, shot, and rampaged my way through anything foolish enough to step in front of me. Prior to this, I had only ever played games like The Legend of Zelda and Sonic, so this was a [u][b]HUGE[/b][/u] step in a hole new direction for me. 
Life was never the same.
Now fast forward 18 years, and hear I am running around the same levels with the same stupid, awestruck smirk across my face. Once the nostalgia wore off, I noticed a few slight differences from the original N64 version I grew up on. The occasional thing moved here, a new enemy there, but it still felt like Turok 2. The controls were simple, the game looked beautiful, it ran better than you can ever ask for, and before I knew it 3 hours had passed by. There was the occasional slight lighting issue, and audio would cut out on a cutscene every now and than, but there were no other reportable problems with this game.
[u][b]Now, the thing to remeber is that this game is dated.[/b][/u]
It's old, and was made in a time when graphics weren't as they are now. However, if you can look past that (and don't mind a few hundred gallons of blood sprayed everywhere), I can guaranty that you'll find hours worth of fun in this game.
Now, as I play more, I'll update my review based on my experiences across the whole game, and what I found while experiencing the multiplayer aspect. I wonder if it will have anything on that good, old fashioned, 4 player split screen madness that the original had.

38643177.review:
Turok 2 is a massive leap over the originol Turok in every way. Thevels are huge, the graphics are detailed and lively, the music is exciting, and the violance and gore is suitably brutal. 

Nightdive went out of their way to make this game more enticing to new players with little quality of life touches like cliff grabbing (for help makeing those tricky jumps) and icons to alert you of important items that are easy to overlook. Turok purists will be happy to know that these can be turned off, though.

I'm impressed with how this game holds up today. Little attentions to detail that were huge features (but taken for granted today) like enemies reacting to shots to different body parts or actually rushing to take cover for an advantage in a fire fight really stood out. And the combat is very satisfying with how beefy the weapons feel and how you can blow chunks off of enemies and cause them to writhe or spasm in their deaththrows. 

The game does has some issues, though. Levels can be confusing and are easy to get lost in. The voice acting is often hard to hear over the other sounds of the game as well. An option to have subtitles would have been nice. But those are small complaints and don't hamper the overall quality of the game and what it has to offer. Nightdive managed to do justice to Turok again and I'm eagerly awaiting Turok 3.

38403472.review:
Being an old fan of Turok 2: Seeds of Evil, there was no way I would not buy this game on Steam. And boy did Nightdive do a great job in remastering this gem of a game.

- Movements feel so much nicer than they used to, it feels extremely rewarding running through maps and shooting everything on sight.
- The enhanced graphics successfully prevent your eyes from turning into square-shaped pixels, though Nightdive did not increase the boobs of the alien girl.
- The hints help a big deal to find the stuff you wanna find in order to get through the game. There are still I believe 30 secret spots with Steam Rewards for the mindful treasure hunter.
- Being able to save at every location is pure sugar. I am finally able to just try whether I can jump into water or whether it's deadly, without having to play the whole map again.

So far so good about Single Player Mode.
Multiplayer on the other hand is a whole different story. Turok 2 used to be THE multiplayer game. Lots of players, lots of servers, lots of fun stuff, cool characters to pick (you could even play the freaking raptor!), colour selection, map selection, capture the flag, arena, team deathmatch and all sorts of shit. I played like a maniac even before ego-shooter became everybody's darling starting with Counterstrike.

- The Multiplayer mode of this version sucks. (did they just convert it from N64??)
- You can not play different characters.
- I have not been able to locate Capture the Flag game mode.
- You can not host a game and select an individual map to play. You can only select a map package.
- Hence, there are no players on servers.
- This is really sad.

However, the single player mode is still nice and I would recommend this game to everyone who doesn't want to play this on Multiplayer.  :(

38124629.review:
It's amazing how Turok 2 was released (December 10, 1998) about a year and a half after the first Turok game (March 4th, 1997) and improved upon the original in almost every single aspect. It has more weapons, enemies, environments, and unlike in the first Turok game this one is much bloodier and very gorey (which is always a good thing of course :) ). I remember playing this as a kid back in the day just like with the first Turok except Turok 2 is much more serious and even has a forbidding tone such as the enemies you fight and the levels you venture into. 

The story is much more developed and brings a bit more immersion (for the time it was released anyways) than Turok: Dinosaur Hunter. You play as Joshua Fireseed who becomes the next Turok after Tal'Set from Turok 1 (which was never really explained unless you read the comics) who must stop the Primagen from escaping his imprisonment of his own doing. The Primagen is an alien life-form with powerful telepathic powers, whose actions in his universe led to the creation of the Lost Land and our universe many eons ago. Realizing the danger he possessed, the elders of the Lost Land erected five Energy Totems in places thought to be vulnerable to the Primagen's power.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here is an excerpt from the Turok wikipedia about the Primagen:

"Long ago, in a universe that no longer exists, there was an alien race of extremely intelligent sentient beings. They had answered many of life's mysteries, with the exception of one: where did all come from?

One of them wanted to answer this very question. His peers tried in vain to stop him. He devised a "time" machine, one which could theoretically allow him to travel back in time and discover the beginning of creation itself.

There was a problem, though: time travel to the past is impossible, as it goes against the very foundation of the universe. His device was a time machine, but not the one he intended to create.

As the Primagen traveled through the Netherscape, bits and pieces of different worlds were dragged along with his Lightship, like a magnet, until he reached what he thought was the beginning of time. When the Lightship came to a stop, matter all around him began collapsing and compressing, and he realized this was his chance to witness what no mortal eyes had ever seen: the birth of the universe, the beginning of time.

As the universe reached its final moments, the hole left by the Lightship in the Netherscape had yet to be closed, and matter dragged by many of the Lightship's power cores began bombarding it. The bombardment de-stabilized the Lightship, sending it towards the One Point, triggering what is known as the Big Bang.

Shortly thereafter, all that was left from this universal display of fireworks was the cosmic, primordial soup that eventually lead to the creation of our universe.

The Big Bang sent the Lightship and its owner back into the Netherscape, sealing him away in a temporal prison of his own making, one way in, no way out.

Constant freak events occur all across our universe, such as objects disappearing to either never be seen again or re-appearing in another world, billions of light years away from their origin. There is a reason for this: the hole left behind in the Netherscape by the Primagen's Lightship allowed for energy from the Big Bang to affect its natural structure, and thus, these bits of pure energy punched holes all across the vastness of the universe.

These holes are in constant flux, always unpredictable. Being sucked into a Netherscape hole is like playing a game of Russian roulette; you will never know if the other side of the portal is either deep inside a planet's core or right in the middle of an intergalactic war."
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Now as to were this information came from I'm not sure maybe from the game manual or something.

All in all I highly recommend this game to anybody willing to give it a try and to the hardcore fans of the original Turok series.

37907198.review:
Beautifully done remaster of a classic hit.  I still own my copy of Turok 2 SOE, on the N64 and I remember the days, I'd stay up late, trying to find my way through the Lair of the Blind Ones. The game left a lasting impression on me and I recall having dreams (err nightmares) of it.  Unlike anything I've played before, during that period of my life.

Today, we now have a remaster of that game and while I was excited to play it, I was also a bit afraid of any changes made to it.   But my fears were put to rest, almost immediately after starting up the game. You'll get that classic Iguana intro and music at the start screen, which put a smile on my face. :)

After punching in 14 hours into it (I'm not done yet!), I can honestly say that I'm very happy with the work done by the developers. A lot of love was put into making this remaster a great experience, with finer image quality (though not a transformation of the original) paired with good sound quality and fast paced action.

The controls are quite sharp, though hit detection can be a pain with smaller enemies, like the spiders and compy dinos, but it's nothing that ruins the game. Use the war blade on the comps and deal with the fact that you're going to get bit at least once and you can safely strafe around the spiders, if you're not into slashing through them. Eventually, you'll have the flame thrower to help you with the nuisance.  

There are also markers around map objectives, to help you, which wasn't present in the original console game.  I'm not sure if one can turn this option off.

Speaking of options, there's many to play with, besides the games graphics and difficutlty. You have your bloom options, brightness settings as well as music style (PC or N64).  

The game play is also much faster than I remember. Very fluid and it almost feels like your flying around.  I appreciate this, after growing accustomed to Doom 2016's speed.  Keeps the action from going stale, imho. Love playing this with the keyboard and mouse!

The game's objectives and maps are recaptured with only a few minor changes done to the Lair of The Blind Ones, which seemed to have made it easier to run through, without constantly making that wrong turn, which puts you back to a spot you've already covered. Some people may or may not appreciate this. It didn't ruin it for me.
 
Honestly, this game is great. Whether you've played the original or not, I'd totally recommend it. It's very fun and captivating, for a game it's age.  Best Turok game ever, imho.


"I AM TUROK!!"

37833583.review:
Turok 2: Seeds of Evil is a wonderful recreation of the N64 original, and a computer version I actually didn't even know about until recently. The game itself runs with all the bells and whistles you would expect. Touched up graphics, no bog down, and in general how you wished it played back in the day (especially on N64). I was a huge fan of the game on console, and though I had the expansion pack, it still ran as clunky as a ten year old washing machine on legs. 

The game is a crude open design, from a day when open exploration games weren't all that common. This game actually does a better job of direction than the first, but it's still easy to get turned around, lost, or just not find one of the many keys needed to open the next level gate. Still, there's a simplicity in the design that feels great if you don't mind wandering around for a bit, dispatching the endless spawning enemies. It holds up well enough today, but certainly shows it's age. It's fun, but not the ideal open world shooter thats since evolved. 

The music is great. It was great when the game released, and it's better now. They've retouched the music, and taken the liberty of putting both the CD quality of the PC version in alongside the N64 set. They're both distinct for their own reasons, and I enjoy switching between the two. It was a nice touch they added in, but didn't have to. Either of the music tracks were great, but having the foresight to add both showed the developers care for their craft. 

Weapon selection is one of those things you don't see too often these days. This game had some of the most distinct weapons of any game, present or past. The Cereberal Bore is legendary in video games, and here is it's birth. Beyond that, the Nuke Staff is so very impressive. The Tek Arrows stood out for their vicious and distinct sound when they charged up and exploded inside an opponent. In general, the detail for these weapons were just a delight. Even that arm sabre thats obtainable is a viciously designed and executed weapon. I would love to see more game designers take variety in weapons design like this game.

Overall, it's a classic. It stands the test of time, even if it stumbles slightly in the pacing. It can be tough at times, you can run out of ammo if you get stuck on a mission too long wandering for a key, and platforming is always hit or miss with 3D titles. All said, it's still great if you like classic games. For anyone who wants to remember what shooters were like, this is a good place to be. For those comfortable with the present, you may find this formula a bit different to your current tastes. For the price, especially on sale, I encourage a buy here. 

-M-

36630019.review:
While the first Turok could be charming in its datedness, Turok 2 is dated in all the worst ways and stands as a validation to the neophilic cretins of the world who think that quality has an expiration date.

Visually, the game is somehow worse than its predecessor. While the first game was pretty barebones in its visuals, I don't recall it having quite so many blatant world edges. Where the first one would cover such things up with a layer of fog or something, this game is lousy with pits that clearly just stop, to the point that in some places you can see big boxy chunks where the developers just stopped building the wall. It creates the effect that the entire game is a crudely-built paper mache obstacle course.

General level design is worse too, largely abandoning the first game's distinctive verticality for an increased emphasis on corridor shooting, though this is admittedly rectified somewhat in the later levels. The attempt at nonlinearity simply serves as proof that nonlinear level design isn't better by default, as the game's reliance on teleporters to break up the level largely destroys any sense of continuity and the levels generally make no effort to visually guide the player, making exploration (which given that each level has specific objectives besides "kill the things and find the exit," is non-optional) a trial-and-error chore. I had one instance where I spent a good half hour scouring a level for the last objective only to find it hidden down a random side passage that I had never noticed because I simply hadn't glanced left at that spot without any indication that I was supposed to.

The game is quick to boast its weapon selection, but much like Half-Life: Opposing Force this selling point is more of a hassle than a boon in practice. With 22 weapons to keep track of (at least, I could honestly be forgetting one or two), trying to find the best tool for the job in the heat of battle is a distracting mess and I often wound up spamming through whatever was convenient or just relying on one or two weapons until they ran out of ammo. Many weapons were outright useless, either rendered redundant by an identical-but-better weapon or simply being unable to keep up with the difficulty curve of the enemies. Even the big assembly weapon of the game - the Nuke - is largely useless because it's not worth using its ammo on lesser creatures and in boss fights it's an impractical time waster because they're invincible 60% of the time and only vulnerabe in certain spots the rest.

Turok 1 had almost no story to it, and the sequel proves that this was for the better as the plot is roughly on par with something you'd find on a cereal box. Not only do dinosaurs barely feature this time around, but the game constantly feels the need to establish how this level's cannon fodder are a) irredeemably evil so it's okay to blast them to chunky bits on sight, but b) also being manipulated by the Big Bad to prove that he's even eviler. The attempt at stringing a story together also seemed to do a number on supplying variety, as the levels are in order: a vaguely acultural ancientish city, a nearly identical vaguely acultural ancientish city, a swamp, a cave beneath a swamp, a techno-organic complex, and a non-organic techno-complex. Each one introduces roughly 2-3 new mobs, none of which besides the basic lizardmen enemies will appear in any of the other levels.

Boring, ugly and clunky, Turok 2 is worse than its predecessor in pretty much every way. Find some other retro-shooter to invest your time in.

36375945.review:
An excellent port of a classic N64 game, which on the original system pushed the old Nintendo to its limits resulting in quite a bit of lag and frame drop. No more, this version runs full pelt on my fairly old laptop. All the good parts are intact, the selection of some of the coolest weapons ever seen in a videogame, the impressive (for its age) AI which sees enemies using cover and attempting to flank you and the mostly fast-paced run and gun gameplay although the maps are sprawling and can be confusing. You'll see switches and items that you won't actually be able to reach until quite later on in the game and because maps are linked with portals it can be quite hard to keep track of where you are. Luckily this new version has a 'hint' mode, which hovers exclaimation marks over important switches and items, even through walls. You can switch this off, but unless you want a real challenge you'll probably want to leave it on because without it it's extremely easy to run straight past a vital item that you'll end up having to backtrack trying to find later on. Even with hints on I still found myself scouring around trying to work out what to do next. I recall when I played the original I was stuck on one particular part of the map for no less than a week because I couldn't find an extremely well hidden switch.

The hint mode alleviates some of this kind of frustration, but not all which is probably as it should be. Nevertheless, this is a great game and well worth the asking price.

36370824.review:
[h1][b]“A Polished Remastered of Classic and Solid FPS Gameplay”[/b][/h1]

Turok 2: Seeds of Evil is a first-person shooter originally developed by Iguana Entertainment (1998) and remastered by Night Dive Studios (2017). It became one of my childhood classics when I started playing FPS at 8 years old.

---------------------------------------------------------
[h1]Return of Dinosaur Hunter[/h1]

Turok 2 was first featured in Nintendo 64. You play as Joshua Fireseed, a member of Native American hero, was assigned the task by female alien named Adon to stop the invasion of Primagen.

The gameplay is pretty straightforward in classic FPS formula. You progress through each world by completing main objective and collecting Primagen keys to unlock the last level. At the end of level you will have to destroy Totem that link to Primagen’s power.

Each world filled with well-crafted design from Hellenistic decoration of Adia city to hi-tech mothership. It’s simple and linear, but multi-layered complexity rewarded you with collectathon life up gameplay (except on hardcore difficulty) and bonus items.

---------------------------------------------------------
[h1]Big Game Hunter[/h1]

Turok 2 captured the feeling of hurting and it’s the strongest point of Turok series; gunplay and enemies. You carry unlimited number of weapons such as traditional bow, shotgun, and harpoon. The more you progress, the more you earn advanced arsenals; laser shotgun, flamethrower, boomerang razor, and cerebral bore (a.k.a brain drilling). There’s variation of enemy types; the dinosaur, the undead, the blind ones, and more. Each of them has their own behavior and attack pattern which make engaging combat and strategy on higher difficult (it’s challenged, but fair). Moreover, the various feedback animations of each enemy are scripted, but very satisfied and brutal to watch. Solid sound design and memorable soundtracks.

Although, the remastered version reduces complexity of some sections, it still remains its labyrinth and some objectives require fully exploration which can be aggravating for some player who enjoy full-action mission. You might experience head-bob issue while moving in default setting. Only few enemies have hit-scan and respawn mechanics every time you switch level can be bit annoy for some players.

---------------------------------------------------------
[h1]Supreme Remastered[/h1]

Night Dive does amazing work on remastered version; polished port and much optimized for modern system. I have solid framerate without single technical issue on my full playthought. The game also offers various graphical customization, improve gameplay, UIs, new multiplayer mode, split-screen, and mod support while preserving its main core. It brings back Turok back to life again with improvement in every aspect.

---------------------------------------------------------

Turok 2 remastered is the long deep single-player and enjoyable multi-player with varied enemies and weapons. It’s massive improvement over original by small studio’s passion which we don’t see much nowadays. Highly recommend considered on quality and support.

36031414.review:
It's a great sequel.  More weapons, more enemy variety, gore system and location based damage is now a thing, enemies react to being shot and THEN SOME, the music is better, and Adon is a great character.  I like her...a lot.  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)﻿

There are less bosses than the first game, but they have multiple phases which caught me off guard.  Also the game is tough.  Much more of a challenge than before.  There's a lot less platforming and there's some quality of life adjustments that make it so that I don't pull what's left of my hair out.  There's more mission variety rather than a simple key hunt like last time.  This game, like it's predecessor, is still something of a collect-a-thon.  Meaning that you collect golden and red triangles to restock your lives.  Also the triangles are arranged so that they guide you through the level subtley.  There's even a part in the game where it guides you to a wall...and it never occured to me to shoot the wall.  Such a thing never came up before.  This is why my playtime is so high for this game.  Sadly, I found myself looking up certain things, locations, and sections while the game was paused.
Yes, the game can be a touch confusing.  However, stick with it and you will be rewarded.  Highly recommended.

Wie ich schon in meiner Review zu Turok: Dinosaur Hunter schrieb, habe ich diese beiden Spiele früher gespielt. Und genau wie Dinosaur Hunter habe ich es selbst mit Cheats nicht durchspielen können.

Die 8 Level sind groß und verwirrend, selbst die überarbeiteten Level des Remasters sind zu verwirrend für mich. 
Das Remaster hat Hinweise welche Objekte mit denen man interagieren kann markiert. Dies zerstört zwar ein bischen das Retrofeeling, war aber für mich ein muss. Trotzdem brauchte ich Guides um alle Schlüssel zu finden.

Der Multiplayer beinhaltet Maps der PC und der N64 Version (leider nicht alle Maps der PC Version aber die hatte auch endlos viele, da ich nicht die N64 Version gespielt habe weiß ich nicht wie viele diese hatte) außerdem beinhaltet es die Waffen welche exklusiv zum N64 Multiplayer waren (Crossbow, Assault Rifle sowie eine abgeänderte Version der Plasma Rifle, Firestorm Cannon, Scorpion Launcher, Grenade Launcher und Charge Dart welche von ihren originalen aus dem Singleplayer abweichen und nur im Rok Mix Modus spielbar sind).
Zudem gibt es einen neuen Modus Namens "Raptor Fest" welcher ein Endlos-Survival-Horden Modus ist in dem man gegen immer stärter werdene Gegner kämpft die immer mehr werden bis man schließlich stirb oder das Kill/Zeit Limit erreicht wenn man eins gesetzt hat.
Zusätzlich ist der Multiplayer mit bis zu 4 Spieler im Splitscreen modus möglich, die FPS können dabei aber deutlich variieren (kleine N64 maps = hohe FPS / große PC maps = niedrige FPS).

Das Spiel bekamm ein Update welches die deutschen Stimmen hinzufügte, auch wenn der Shop bei Ton kein Häkchen hat!

Ich empfehle Turok 2: Seeds of Evil allen welche es früher gespielt habe oder alte Shooter mögen, aber allen anderen nicht wirklich.

Ich hoffe dass Nightdive Studios das beendet was die begonnen haben und alle restlichen Turok Spiele ebenfalls Remastern.
Das wären noch Turok 3: Shadow of Oblivion, Turok: Rage Wars, Turok: Evolution und das Turok Reboot von 2008.

35759323.review:
Turok Dinosaur Hunter on the Nintendo 64 was my favorite shooter on the system, even rivalling Goldeneye 007. I loved the world, the violence and the weaponry. So the day Turok 2 came out was a good day indeed. However, it ran like mud on the N64 even with the extra memory, like 20'ish fps at most - and was difficult beyond belief. I got so stuck in the Lair of the Blind Ones that I'm pretty sure I went insane at some point before finally finding those two switches.

Anyway, Turok 2 on the PC fixes every problem I had with it on the Nintendo 64. It runs smoothly at 60fps, controls like a modern shooter and looks as good as it should without killing the original look. It's all great. It's a great port.

[b] The good:[/b] 

The game is bigger and more complex. The worlds are different and the enemies are varied enough. The weaponry is as imaginative as ever, with the Cerebral Bore being the big star back in the day because of the over the top violence. My favorite weapons from the game is probably the Tek Bow, because of the challenging headshots, and the Shotgun with explosive shells for those precise insta-kills.

[b] The Bad:[/b] 

The game is bigger and more complex. The complex part makes it confusing at times, and the level design is not all that memorable - making stumbling around levels looking for things you might have missed (and you will miss them) a little annoying at times. And when you have found all the levels and gone through them all, you still need to find the sacred feathers and primagen keys - so there will be a lot of backtracking. It's a lot of fun opening up places you couldn't reach before, sure, but the level design again kills a little of that fun.

[b] Conclusion:[/b] 

Turok 2: Seeds of Evil is a true sequel, in that its more of everything. More of what made the original so great, more great weapons and more violence. But also bigger and more complex than it needs to be, and it loses some of the light fun the original had in the process. Good game, but not great.

[b] 7/10[/b]

This is a fun late 1990s shooter.  I'll admit a bit of nostalgia as I had this one for the N64.  However, it holds up remarkably well almost 20 years after it was originally released.  Looking back, this was definitely one of those games that was "ahead" of its time.

Pros:
+Great fast paced FPS
+A huge variety of weapons
+A huge variety of fun enemies to fight
+You can revisit any location in a level
+The levels are generally varied and fun
+A nice difficulty curve, as you start off with weak weapons and slowly amass a god-like arsenal
+The developer added quick travel stations
+Save anywhere function

Cons:
-Suffers from late 1990s video game design (jumping puzzles)
-The bosses have bs damage that you oftentimes can't avoid
-I had some crashes surrounding saving/loading my game

Tip: I recommend playing level three before level two.  It makes it much less annoying.

34150716.review:
Честно говоря сложно дать конкретную оценку. Моя положительная оценка - это оценка за качество ремастера. Авторы честно попытались максимально сгладить недостатки оригинала. Улучшения следующие:
1. Туман настолько далеко, что уже не мешает.
2. Игра работает без глюков и косяков.
2. Все активные точки и важные разрушаемые объекты помечены. Отметки видны даже сквозь стены.
Поэтому если у вас игра вызывает ностальгические чуства - смело берите (Эта игра поставлялась с видеокартой моего первого собственного компьютера, который мне купили в честь поступления в институт в 1999г. Соответственно, это первая игра которую я на нём запустил) 
Для остальных игроков я, увы, не могу эту игру однозначно рекомендовать. Это не самый выдающийся шутер. Историческое значение у этой игры (во всяком случае у ПК версии) минимальное. В отличии от первого Турка, эта игра была вынуждена конкурировать с Unreal, Half-Life и Sin, которые превосходили Турок 2 по всем статьям (не говоря уж о том, что портирована она была мягко говоря небезупречно). 
Основная проблема игры - это то что для прохождения каждого уровня не обходимо выполнить ряд заданий. Уровни длинные, запутанные и свернув  не туда ты можешь запросто пропустить цель миссии, даже не заметив этого. В результате в конце уровня ты с удивлением обнаружишь, что игра просто отправляет тебя в начало уровня. Для прохождения игры необходимо также собрать дополнительные предметы , что требует проходить уровни ещё как минимум по разу. 
Стрельба тоже не самая лучшая.

34089415.review:
Turok 2: Seeds of Evil dürfte einigen noch ein Begriff von früher sein.
Die erste Frage: ist dieses Spiel denn überhaupt die knapp 20€ wert? Meine Antwort: Ja, dass ist es.
Dieses Remastered merzt die Fehler des Originals vollkommen aus, sowohl grafisch, als auch spielerisch.
Das Headbobbing ist deutlich angenehmer (Turok wackelt nicht mehr so eklig mit den Waffen hin und her & man bekommt keine Motion-Sickness :D), der Distanznebel, der im Original oftmals Schwierigkeiten bereitet hat, ist vollkommen weg, schöne Licht/Schatteneffekte, flüssiges Gameplay, eine sehr angenehme Steuerung & ein Achievement System, polieren das Spiel auf Hochglanz.
Pro / Contra:
+ Fette Waffen (Gehirnbohrer, 4-Raketenwerfer, Minigun und noch vieeeeeeeeel mehr ^^)
+ Uncut (Gore Effekte kommen hier noch besser zur Geltung)
+ Bombastischer Soundtrack
+ gut durchdachtes Leveldesign 
+ Nette Hilfseinlagen (Hinweise werden angezeigt), die man aber auch ausschalten kann
+ sowohl Deutsche, als auch Englische Synchro
+ Spieldauer (Man hat das Spiel weder zu schnell durch, noch dauert es ewig, ich hab mit normaler Spielweise 10h gebraucht)
+ Spielbarkeit: Angenehmes Gameplay, gute Spielbarkeit aufgrund des Levelaufbaus (man kann es locker mehrmals hintereinander spielen, ohne dass es langweilig wird)
+ (mit die beste Neuerung) Es gibt nun eine SCHNELL WARP FUNKTION (endlich!!!) - wenn man Backtracking aufgrund von Schlüsseln betreiben muss, kann man das jetzt locker flockig machen, ohne den ganzen Level von A-Z durchzurotzen
- Die Story (recht dünn, aber auf die kommt es auch weniger an)
Ansonsten fällt mir nichts weiter an negativen Aspekten ein.
9,5/10 kriegt Turok 2 von mir, und eine ganz klare Empfehlung!

33989426.review:
Sequel with much more variety and even bigger levels than its predecessor

PRO:
+ Original gameplay with rather subtle visual improvements and convenience features (e.g. turn off intros, skip death sequences or eliminate head bobbing)
+ Six massively huge levels which often require backtracking to collect everything
+ Every level has a different look and enemies (other than in the first Turok)
+ Motivating hunt for Nuke Weapon, Talisman feathers, Primagen keys and secrets in general
+ More story with objectives to complete in each level
+ Option to switch between N64 and PC soundtrack via menu
+ Free saving (plus quicksave option)

CON:
- Levels are almost too huge at times - it's easy to get lost (especially the Lair of the Blind Ones)
- Some objectives and secrets are quite difficult to find (e.g. unlocking the Primagen key in level 6)
- There could be a few more checkpoints in some levels to cover more ground quickly via warp feature

Verdict:
Turok 2 is a huge improvement over the original game with quicksave option, acceptable jumping sequences, great variety of locations, awesome soundtrack, and objective-driven level design. Its massive levels can take you 1-2 hours each, and even after that you will have to return later after collecting Talismans which allow you to reach areas in some levels which you could not access before. Other than the first Turok, I can recommend this game without any restrictions. It is enjoyable, entertaining, does not get boring over time and has a huge load of weapons for you to collect and use on a wide range of enemies. I especially liked that you finally know what you are doing, with different missions for each level and some background story narrated by NPC Adon. If you like shooters, you should not miss this one!

33910501.review:
Turok 2: Seeds of Evil is a 1998 N64/PC first person shooter sequel to Turok: Dinosaur Hunter where you play as a new Turok, Joshua Fireseed, as he under goes his quest to stop the forces of Oblivion from taking over the universe.

While Turok: Dinosaur Hunter was an experimentation with what people could do with shooters at the time, Turok 2 feels far more realized than the first game in the series. Turok 1's main objective was to find level keys just so you could continue. Turok 2 on the other hand keeps the level keys, but also gives you numerous objectives per level to complete. As an example, the first map in this game, The Port of Adia, tasks you with saving 4 children and activating 3 distress beacons. The overall MAIN objective of each level however, is finding and protecting an energy totem from Oblivion's forces. These totem challenges will test your mettle by the end of the game, with absolute swarms attacking it as soon as you warp into the totem challenge.

Guns GALORE. Seriously man if you don't know what the Cerebral Bore is you are a fuckin' mongo. Ammo types! Explosive Arrows! A Nuke Launcher! Flamethrowers and Plasma Guns! Plenty of options for your carnage needs friend.

The only issue everyone seems to point out with this game is map length. There aren't that many levels in the game, but Acclaim made up for that fact by nearly doubling the length of every map in the game. Turok 1 had some decent sized maps but Turok 2 turned that way up. Thankfully, unlike the first game, this remaster has the classic save and load anywhere function, so you do not have to rely on checkpoints to save your progress. 

Turok 2 has and will forever be my favorite game made by Acclaim. I'm hoping that the sales of both Turok 1 and 2 drive nightdive to finish the series with Turok 3 and Turok: Evolution. This game is not for everybody, but if you can pace yourself, and really take in the enviroments, you'll find one hell of a top notch shooting experience in this game.

33871855.review: Argueably the best in the series, remastered for modern computers. A crazy good time, and the gameplay holds up very well by today's standards. Weapons are all unique and satisfying to use and the levels are HUGE for a game from the N64 days. Equal parts nostalgia and good FPS fun.

33864091.review:
First of all I’ve got to say that I’m not a native english speaker so I apologize beforehand for any error or misunderstanding in the review, but I want this to get to as many people as possible, or at least for the developers of the game to be able to understand it if somehow they get to read this review (unlikely, but still...)

I’ll give a little context: I was born in 1993. I think that I was about 7 or 8 years old when I first got my hands on this game for the N64, and with my cousin we spent lots of days and nights playing with it (the good old days, our parents didn’t even know what we were playing at). By then all we could do was entering the super cheat and have fun with it exploring the levels and getting lost, or just kill each other in the multiplayer mode, because the campaign was, obviously, too complicated for us.

Now let’s go to the present (almost). It wasn’t until a few years ago, maybe at age 16 or 18, that I took my old N64 and decided to take this game seriously. I WAS AMAZED. I had read on some forums on the internet that modern games were too easy and simple, and that Turok 2 was the perfect example of how back then good games were elaborate, and well, I just couldn’t agree more with that fact. I completed the whole campaign once and then played each level again 2 or 3 times (with the exception of Port of Adia, the only level I could pass as a kid), and after that I realized that… it wasn’t that hard at all! After the first try I could easily remember where were all the key objects, even in the infamous Lair of the Blind Ones. All you had to do was to use the map to not get lost because, of course, no one would be so stupid to try and memorize it. I ended falling in love with the game and the design of the levels knowing that no modern game could give me that weird sensation of frustration mixed with self-accomplishment.

So as you can imagine I couldn’t be more hyped when I read about Night Dive Studios remastering Turok 2. I waited until I was on summer holidays to buy it and well… starting from Port of Adia I notice some GOOD modifications on the design of the level: the portal to the main hub at the beginning, more enemies (well done, the ammo is almost infinite in this game), and the new zone in the ports where the beacons were located (I always thought it was stupid to separate both zones with a teleport when they were connected actually). On the other hand the “grappling ledges” thing was totally unnecessary because it forced the developers to make some stupid changes, the location of the first Ultra Health being an example, but well, I could get along with that. Then I go with the River of Souls… short summary: the objectives were relocated so you couldn’t accidentally skip them, destroying the essence of the game. The original version had that added bonus of exploration that it made the game what it was, and now the level was almost lineal, GREAT (SARCASM). As you can see I still remember perfectly the distribution of PoA an RoS and while the changes where overall positive in the first one. I stop playing, go to the forums and… surprise! The same thing happened to the Lair of the Blind Ones!!! And hilariously there’s and achievement for that level, what a joke…

I’ve seen somebody in another review complaining about the same things, and the answer from another steam user was that all those things were foretold (because the developers thought that some zones had unnecessary maze-like structures), so I’ve got to recognize it: MY BAD, I didn’t mind to get enough information on the product I was buying. But then it is not a remastered version of Turok 2, it is a modification with improved graphics and performance. You can’t imagine how sorry I am to have to make this negative review (the only one I ever made in Steam), I suppose I was too hyped and my intention is not to hate, but I'll have to ask for a refund.

PS: I still recommend this game as it’s the best port you’ll find, particularly if you like 20 year old videogames and FPS, and never played it before, or even if you played it but don’t remember it as well as me (most of the players haven’t minded the changes or simply haven’t noticed them).

PSS: Again sorry for my english if I haven’t explained something well enough.

33647247.review:
Oh man. When I played this version for the first time, great memories of the N64 came flooding back. However I'd like to point out. First of all, even though this is remastered the graphic changes are barely noticeable. The only type of graphics that I know that changed is the lighting but there's so little darkness in the first level that it seems I don't even need a flashlight (In later levels, the flashlight becomes more useful).
The second thing is the cheats. This is very personal and I find it quite funny in some ways but I just want to ask, why did they put this in the game. It's when you turn on any cheat, even if it makes the game funny or even harder (Like the mode that makes the world very hard to see) Adon will say things like "Oh, does that make you feel good?" or "You should be ashamed of yourself". The fact that this game doesn't like it when you use cheats just kicks me in the balls. Cheats in single player is harmless and it seems the developers for this remastered version didn't take the hint. Only cheaters in multiplayer should be punished as it ruins everyone else's fun. In single player, it's just for personal preference. (Please don't complain about me using cheats, I played the game without them too.)
The last thing I want to point out is the sounds. This might just be me but some sounds in this game makes me miss the old sounds. Unlike the music, you can't change the settings to play the N64 sounds.

Speaking of the music, here's some good points. I wish I can do this with the sound effects but I like the idea of being able to change the music from the N64 version to the PC remastered version. This way you can listen to the old music for that nostalgia effect or you can switch to the remastered music to see how much has changed.
The difficulty is just as hard as the old version too. Of course there's the 4th level which is easy to get lost in which no one likes. But the developer made fun of it by making an achievement for getting all objectives and keys in that damn place just because of how hard it is. Part of me hates that idea but the other part loves it as we all remember how annoying it was. The only change in difficulty that I found was the enemy AI. Enemies can now see you from really far away. Which makes them more unpredictable.
I have noticed while testing the weapons that the lag caused by the flamethrower, scorpion launcher and the grenade launcher has been fixed. The N64 made those weapons cause the game to slow down while the remastered version allowed them to let the game run so smoothly. I also noticed that the damage they do is a lot more realistic. The PFM layer tears pretty much any enemies' legs off like it should. All explosives tear enemies apart like a real explosive weapon while the old version for some reason made them completely immune to it at random times.
There's a particular cheat that allows the player to memorise the level maps a lot easier, even the Lair of the Blind Ones. That's the Fly ability. It could have been better if you can move through walls like the first game but I can tolerate it. If the 4th level is too hard, just play the game again with the cheats and just memorise the map as much as you can.

I have noticed a glitch in the game. In the second level you need to open a gate to get to the trap portal making you pull a few switches and fight through some spiders. But there's a gap where you get a full health which is possible to jump across. If you run diagonally you move faster and jump further allowing you to jump across the gap with ease. At this point you'll notice that all the enemies in the portal room are gone.
The reason why I didn't put this in with the cons is because it can be a great tactic for speed running the game. I'd really want to see this game get beaten in just a few hours.

Now would I recommend it. I'll say yes. Even to those who haven't played the N64 version before. Yeah, it's bloody but that's what makes Turok so great. And yes, the graphics are not the most aesthetically pleasing but that doesn't make this a bad game. I love this game so much and it's worth every cent. Plus, it's really hard to get the N64 version these days so this is a good way to get the game.

33644272.review:
Oh yes, yes, a million times YES! Turok 2 may be easily enjoyed by anyone with a passing interest in classic-style FPSes, where outlandish blocky graphics were the norm, the only time you looked through a sight was for the resident sniper and the finest aim you had was the quickness of your wrist or the litheness of your thumb. Having surfacely played the first Turok on an old PC way back when, then playing it via emulator on Wii N64, I arrived at a Steam sale and thought to get the first Turok, but the reviews were clear: don't bother - its map design isn't the best and a constant guide is required. Thus I turned my attention to this. It's by far the superior game in every way- a greater selection of weapons, variety in environments and tighter map design. Eagle-eyed aim is rewarded as I found out by going full headhunter mode with quick enemy deaths that spill out brilliant gloopy alien blood in such a classic way.

Maybe get the first Turok cheap if you have to, but the story of the first game barely ties into this. Then again, it's a mid-late 90's FPS. Story in games still followed Romero's Law.

Some people may be put off by the 3D hints displayed in game, that float in front of important switches or passageways. I say, f**k those elitist pri*ks. I'm sure they can be turned off but the main meat of the game is the enemies you face. Besides the 3D hints are no help if what you need is behind a wall.

Wholly reccomended for shooter fans.

33468975.review:
Twenty years.
Twenty years of uncertainty. 
Of strife. 
Of doubt.
A child I was, scarcely capable of facing each new dawn, let alone countless beasts of reptilian origins. Yet, I had conquered some of the mightiest titans of the era: 
Goldeneye, Legend of Zelda, Super Mario 64. 
But Turok? No...that cartridge, black as coal, left my soul hollow and cold. Lost and shrouded in confusion, I wandered the Port of Adia for hours, looking for the final child. That pitiful, broken child. 
Looking back, I want so desperately to blame the controller, that twisted amalgamation of plastic and pain. But, I cannot. 
It was my own failure. 

Then this. This beacon, screaming out from beyond the veil of shadow, at last found me. The rendering, the sound, the music, THE CONTROLS...
I faced the prehistoric hordes once more. 
Through wit and will, I perservered. I slaughtered. I conquered. 
A chapter long since started has finally been completed. Nothing is as it was. 
My life has changed, and for that, I will forever be thankful.

33467700.review:
I have to say Nightdive Studios has done an excellent job porting this classic game to PC.
When I bought this I thought"well..It´s not expensive..I just add it on my game collection"
Now I have 5o hours of playtime..And that´s on the single player!
There seems to be many options for multiplayer,but I just tested it(I´m not a multiplayer type so server etc..is confusing to me..But what comes to that i´m novice)..There was nice amount of maps for multi and Raptor fest was my favorite(even I was playing alone at the moment)because there were dinos spawning constantly..
The plot is usual"Earth is in danger"and you must step on the boots of Turok..
There are six levels..But those are huge..
You obtain new weapons as you progress,collect keys to open levels and talismans that grant you special powers which help you get access to seemingly unreachable areas..

I liked this..

33465440.review:
The controls bro, the controls.

They did amazing things with the controls. This game controls as well as CS:GO does, no joke. The sensitivity can be perfectly adjusted, the hitboxes intricate allowing for rewarding headshots/precise shooting at vital spots, you can even manuever yourself midjumps like in CS:GO.

Higher budget titles couldn't get this right, you have games where the sensitivity is just a hopeless cause. Not here though, this is what matters in an FPS and it is SPOT ON. What bewilders me most is, I played this on the N64. I know how it used to control. Basically we went from trying to move dead elephant carcasses to having a glowing hot knife going through butter.

Huge thumbs up, definitely recommend, amazing things done, never seen a better re-release of an old game. These guys know what matters.

You know, here I am browsing steam and this pops up on the main page. I couldn't believe a classic game like this was remastered and I didn't even hesitate to purchase it. 33371505.review:
This was the first mature first person shooter I ever played when I was a kid. This game has always held a special place for me and is one of the big ones that kickstarted a lifetime of gaming. 

In its heyday this game was a cut above the rest. The weapons were so detailed with many moving parts, and the imagination in their design makes each one so memorable. The way the enemies explode into entrails when you hit them with a Scorpion Missile, or how their arms and heads blow off when your Tek Arrows find their mark, and not least of all the unforgettable Cerebral Bore kills; the attention to detail in the models and their animations was just so far ahead of the other N64 games of the era. 

The level design is still so intricate and varied with many secret paths that can be easily overlooked. Even having played the game over and over in my youth I still found this game so difficult to beat (I dont remember the levels being so damn long)! 

As with Turok 1, Night Dive have done a great job remastering this game. It would have been nice if they had added a few more animations and a bit of pizzazz, but they have stayed true to the source material which is always a safe move. One thing I did notice was that on hardcore the era-appropriate difficulty spikes are really very frustrating, even more so than Turok 1 (which was quite easy on the hardest difficulty). But maybe modern gaming has softened me up.

Still, this remaster has brought back many fond memories and it has stayed true to the original game. 

I had a great time!

bewareoblivionisathand

33298016.review:
After playing and disliking the first one I was really hesitant to go after this one.  The difference being I did play Turok back in the day but I hadn't played this one.  I was expecting more of the same.

Happily this one feels like a massive improvement in every way.  The environments feel a lot better to explore.  The objectives make it feel like you're making progress, rather than just drifting through levels aimlessly.  Also there seems to be a lack of that irritating fog this time around, or at least the draw distance is so much better.

The only thing is the movement still feels floaty and imprecise.  Combined with the framerate it actually starts to make me feel ill after playing it for a while, but then I actually have that issue with a few other fps style games with a similar movement feel.  (I can't play Wolfenstein 3D for more than a few minutes on a modern machine before feeling sick all day)

Overall though, I heartily recommend this one.  So much better than its predecessor.  This really does feel like a classic fps in every definition of the word.

33291323.review:
Turok 2 is a classic as far as older-generation FPS titles go.  Expanding much upon what it's predecessor accomplished, this second installment brings new and epic locales to explore, each with their own distinct feeling and setting.

The graphics were stunning for their time, and the level design stills holds its own today.  The large variety of memorable weapons and enemies means that there is never a dull moment in any of the six sprawling maps the game offers.

Having grown up with the original on the Nintendo 64, there was no bound to the excitement I felt when a proper PC port was inevitably announced after the first game's remaster.  However, veteran Turok players should keep in mind the few tweaks that this version has brought along with it.  In addition to the added PC controls, this port also has a few changes in dynamic lighting, slight map changes, some moved item and enemy locations, and a new ability to fast-travel between pink portals (originally used as saves in the N64 version).

All in all, this game is a masterpiece with incredible level and music design, and this all transfers beautifully to this Steam incarnation.  Whether your a classic Nintendo 64 fan, or a lover of first person shooters, this game is a must try!

Шутер старой школы, только для олдфагов, сложный

32973204.review:
Turok 2: Seeds of Evil es un título que disfrutará cualquier jugador de la vieja guardia, y jugadores de la nueva generación, si lo saben apreciar.  Si alguna vez jugaste el título original para N64, y sabes lo que involucraba invertir para poder jugarlo, ahora jugarlo en PC y tener una experiencia de juego renovada es muy satisfactorio.  Texturas renovadas, mayor resolución, controles más intuitivos y una banda sonora renovada, hacen de este juego un homenaje digno del título para la consola... y lo mejor, ya no se necesita un Expansion Pack ni un Memory pack para poder sacarle provecho y avanzar sin complicaciones (el que pasó por esta época, sabe de qué hablo). Adicionalmente integra los mapas de multijugador de la consola, mapas exclusivos de la versión original para PC, mapas nuevos y modos de juego multijugador nuevos, incluyendo la posibilidad de jugar una partida local en pantalla dividida, como en aquella época, o una partida en línea de hasta 16 jugadores.

Para los jugadores "millenium", las nuevas generaciones que dan críticas negativas por no saber lo que era realmente un buen título, este fue uno de los mejores shooters del momento cuando se lanzó originalmente, y lo recomiendo mucho personalmente. Se les advierte que este no es otro shooter lineal y simple, es un juego de tipo FPS que tiene una dificultad muy alta, niveles bastante extensos y laberínticos, requiere mucho tiempo de exploración (ser detallista), saber administrar recursos y tener estrategias para eliminar enemigos de la forma más rápida y "económica", tiene un gran variedad de armas

En mi experiencia personal, me siento muy satisfecho con el juego, pues superó mis expectativas con respecto al título original, y está muy bien dotado con los elementos adicionales y mejorados de la versión remasterizada. Lo recomiendo mucho, y es un clásico que se debe tener.

========================================
|| Desde aquí es algo de historia y experiencias de juego ||
========================================

Cuando adquirí Turok 2 la primera vez, rentado, para la consola N64, me esperaba encontrarme con "otro FPS más" como muchos otros títulos, y escuchando comentarios de otros diciendo que apenas eran 6 niveles en total me resultaba fácil pensar en algo similar a Doom, pero éste no fue el caso.  Para mí fue el juego que más me retó, que más me frustró y el que más disfruté, y que puedo decir que lo seguiré disfrutando por mucho más tiempo.

En esa época (~1998) el N64 era una consola que tenía muchos títulos cuyos datos de partidas podían ser almacenados directamente en el cartucho, pero en el caso de los títulos más complejos, como es el caso de Turok 2, dependía de 2 accesorios adicionales, un Expansion Pack y un Memory Pack, el primero era necesario para poder disfrutar de una mayor resolución de imágen y fluidez, no era obligatorio, pero mejoraba mucho la experiencia de juego; y el segundo era obligatorio para salvar la partida, y si no lo tenías había sólo dos opciones: 1. dejabas la consola encendida hasta terminar el juego, cosa que era inconcebible, ó 2. Apagar e iniciar una partida nueva la próxima vez.

En mi caso debía optar por la segunda, e iniciaba el juego muchas veces con gusto, día a día, y realmente sólo con el objetivo de probar suerte y habilidad para poder completar el nivel 1.  Sí, aquí esto no parece la gran cosa para los que no han tenido su experiencia, pero el punto es que, para poder finalizar ese primer nivel, tuve que valerme de una guía que casualmente encontré en una revista mucho tiempo después (hablamos del tiempo antes del Internet), y demoré, con guía en mano, unas 10 horas contínuas de juego para poder completar, finalmente, el nivel 1.  Y luego de saber completar a la perfección el nivel 1, aún así es una tarea que lleva alrededor de 1 a 2 horas, según la dificultad.

Ahora, luego de muchos años de tener el título original y de jugarlo muchas veces, sin avanzar en lo absoluto realmente, me encontré con el lanzamiento del proyecto de Turok 2 remasterizado para PC.  Lo primero que pasó por mi cabeza fue: "voy a poder guardar la partida para avanzar".  Para resumir mi experiencia con esta nueva edición, en el modo historia, inicié el juego directamente en el modo difícil, para adaptarme, y en este momento llevo más de 12 horas de juego y estoy iniciando el nivel 4, y no sé cuánto más me demoraré, teniendo en cuenta que hay que regresar regularmente a los niveles anteriores a adquirir elementos que sólo es posible obtener con habilidades de niveles posteriores. Hasta el momento puedo decir que no he encontrado fallos y he tenido una experiencia de juego bastante "limpia y muy agradable"

Y para quienes son curiosos y quieren un vistazo rápido a la apertura y complejidad que tiene el título, la clave maestra que desbloquea todo el contenido del juego, es el nombre de uno de los logros... o en su defecto busquen las claves que había para el juego en el N64.

32903330.review:
The best title in the Turok saga follows Joshua Fireseed as he tries to save the universe, generally while putting lots of holes in the bad guys. We've got dinosaurs, dinosaur cyborg super soldiers, apes with miniguns, interdimensional horrors, and all the firearms you'll need to blow them to bits. This game is incredibly creative and fun, and remains one of the most imaginative titles of this era. The levels are mazes, very easy to get lost in and miss critical items, which would be my one complaint. Apart from that, this is a straight forward science fiction shoot em up that never stops throwing bad guys your way, so you'll never stop having fun. 
Just one question. 
Why in the hell isn't Part 3 on Steam yet!?

32861867.review:
It is a fun game, the many weapons feel great and the "hit-feedback" from enemies is almost unparalleled to this day. Its great to watch them tumble over, loose limps and die in the most melodramatic way possible. 
There is also a great varity of them, you will meet new types in every new level. The Maps themselves are also very different from eachother.  with everyone having a unique look.
Graphics are great for a console game of the time (with great improvements in this remaster, without compromising the original look), animations are top notch and even today great to look at.

But not all is gold here. There is a reason why i never finished Turok 2 on the n64 (beside maybe being too young). All the maps are quite big and at times mazelike as hell and you have to look in every corner because you have to find a lot of stuff to procide. But you can be as cautios as you want to, you will have to come back to previous maps because for some Parts or keys lyou need special abilitys you only can collect with other abilities in other levels. At one Point i missed 1 crystal-or-something and i had to search for an houf to find it. The remaster improved here a lot with new visual clues for important items etc, but it still can be pretty annoying.

Another issu for me was the small amount of ammo you get for the weapons, i guess the original developers did this so you would also use the more obscure weapons, in that regard it worked, but for my taste i ran out of ammo for my favourite weapons too fast.

all said and done, i would devinitly recommend trying Turok 2, it is a great shooter with a lot to see and find. Some of the levels are too long and complicated, but with night dives additions it is not nearly as frustrating as it was on the n64!

32749083.review:
Nightdive has outdone themselves, Turok 2's remaster is near perfect. 

Turok 2 itself is an amazing game with impressive graphics for the N64, great sound design and brutal combat across huge levels. Now you take that winning receipe, put it on PC with proper controls, new graphical options, quality of life features, mod support, and 60FPS? You got something special. Not to mention the PC soundtrack is included as an option, a very nice touch.

Beyond this, Nightdive has been supporting the game well with monthly updates that include tons of bugfixes, optimization and even new or requested features. To the point that they included an actual HORDE MODE multiplayer mode!

 I could spend the rest of this review praising how great and supportive of a developer they are, despite Turok being a niche product in of itself they have committed to making this the best it could be.

At 20 Dollars, it sounds steep, but consider that unsupported, unremastered games go for 10-15 on steam. You're supporting a small niche developer that focuses on taking care of old forgotten games and you're paying for not only Turok 2 but every improvement and feature added onto it. I have spent money on worse

You forget just how incredible and enduring this game is until you play it again. Absolutely loved it as a kid and drew me in with the many characters and worlds you are introduced to. Now that it is remastered with better graphics and completely fixed lag issues, it provides the turok experience I always wished I had. Somehow the explosive blood effects seem to have gotten even more spectacular. The map, soundtrack, enemies, bosses and weapons...my god the weapons. The selection and variety of death dealing tools in this game is fantastic. You don't realize just how ahead of its time this game was when it was released. If Nightdive released turok 3 or turok ragewars I would order them in a heartbeat.

A superb port of one of the best old shooters!
This remastered version works flawlessly on my modern PC, which makes me happy! Because the last time when I tried to play the original Turok 2 a year or so ago, it was crashing constantly.

Remastered version works on dx10 and has lots of new graphical options. I do not care about graphics all that much, but Turok 2 is an old game and frankly, kinda ugly. So new effects, as well as full HD and 125% resolution scale, help a bit.

31929088.review:
It's back, gloriously it's back. Turok 2 is the sequel to the N64 hit Turok, remastered and looking better than it ever did on the N64.

In Turok 2 you play as Turok, a Native American warrior chosen to defend Earth from interdimensional threats. This time the Primagen has come, unsealed after thousands of years its up to our favorite Dino blasting hero to blast some Dinos and save the day.

Turok 2 is an FPS and has loads of interesting weapons at your disposal. Of course you begin with the mundane, pistol and a bow. But quickly you gather up exploding bolts, and energy shotgun that literally shreds the enemy, and of course the Ceberal Bore, which drills into the bad guys head and.....explodes. Great fun to be had for all. With the PC controls or using a gamepad/controller, the controls are tight. Aiming is less precise, considering this is an N64 game, and it does get annoying to not be able to zero in on your target. This is slightly forgiven when more powerful weapons are obtained.

The level design however is sorely lacking. Each level tasks you with finding several things, and the levels are sprawling. Multiple paths, hidden paths, teleporters to other realms, it can be a little over whelming. Luckily a handy overlay of the area can be summoned, giving you an exact location as to where you are in the current area. This is great, but still doesn't take away the fact that there are a ton of things to collect. Aside from the main objectives, there are runes to collect to unlock more levels, weapon parts, keys, its quite a lot. If you do plan to play, plan a several hour session. However, there are teleporters around, allowing quick jumps to different sections.

With the remasting of the graphics, so does the sound get remastered. You can play the game with the original score, but the remastered just sounds so much better. All the weapons sound great, and powerful. The pistol sounds wimpy, while the whine of that Cerebral Bore is certain to make you whince at least once. The enemies also sound amazing, with dinosaurs sounding scary, as well as many of the more unique enemy types.

If your looking for a nostalgia trip, or your a young punk who has no idea what an N64 is (Nintendo 64), Turok delivers.

31890737.review:
Turok 2: Seeds of Evil is the sequel to Turok: Dinosaur Hunter, a very good game with a few issues. Turok 2 resolves a lot of those issues, adds some fun new stuff in, and ends up with a really excellent product.

There are actual voice-acted cutscenes and plot now, which is interesting. The plot itself is fairly standard (bad guy wants to take over a place, you have to stop him), but there's backstory for a lot of locations, motivation for a lot of enemies, and an actually well-crafted sequel hook. It's nice to see that effort was put in, and the game's story is generally alright.

The game looks good (for its time) and animates great. Areas are bright and colorful, enemies are astonishingly expressive, and physics seem weighty and realistic.

A lot of mechanics and gameplay elements are carried over from Turok 1, including the lives system, the idea of a handful of giant levels instead of many smaller ones, a few weapons, some enemies, and the solid platforming with no fall damage. However, there're a fair amount of new ideas added to the gameplay too, such as reclaimable arrows, a rideable armed dinosaur, checkpoints that give you health and ammo and allow fast-travel, and upgrades to help you find certain collectibles which are now scattered throughout levels.

Those collectibles are the main difference between Turok 1 and 2. In addition to the level keys from the last game, Turok 2 adds additional (yet necessary to continue) objectives to every level. These mostly involve running up to something and pressing a button or using an item that you picked up in the same area, but the problem is that they're often really well-hidden. Combined with the expansive, complex nature of the level design, this leads to a shit-ton of backtracking and looking stuff up to try and find the last necessary location. Complementing these objectives are pickups for upgrades and new weapons that are similarly well-hidden or spread out. You can spend an hour or two longer than necessary picking a level clean for everything that you need to progress, slowing the otherwise-fun gameplay to an absolute standstill. The level design also lacks the intuitiveness of the first game, so it's far easier to get lost and completely stuck. This is Turok 2's main fault, which is a shame, because everything else works so well.

On the more positive side of things, Turok 2 does a lot to correct the first game's faults. You can switch ammo types now, and enemy respawn rates are down. The armor's gone, which I don't mind because it wasn't really that necessary in the original.

The weapon variety is insanely good. All the traditional weapons are still present (pistol, shotgun, etc.), but there are some really crazy ones added in. The War Blade is one of the most overpowered melee weapons I've seen in a while, there's a minethrower and an auto-pistol and a thing that fires shotgun shells in a sort of bouncing sniper-shot, and then there's the Cerebral Bore, which is one of the most amazing video game weapons I've ever encountered.

Complementing the weapons is the gore system. Turok 1 was more bloody than gory, but this game kicks both of those things to 11. Blood splatters, gushes, and pools, enemies twitch and jerk on death, and you can remove heads and limbs if you aim at them. At one point I blew an enemy's entire top half off. The sound design adds a lot, too, adding screams, spurting noises, and the sound of enemies choking on their own blood. This is one of the most amazingly violent games I've ever seen, and it's a goddamn N64 title.

Apparently the main character is a different guy also named Turok.

This Steam port is also really good. The game seems to be far more crisp and colorful than the original, a quicksave feature seems to have been implemented (making the lives system obsolete), the auto-aim is gone so you actually have to try and hit things, and overall it just seems like a lot of love went into it. Night Dive Studios really seem to put some effort into reviving classics, and it shows.

Overall, Turok 2: Seeds of Evil is even better than Turok: Dinosaur Hunter. It plays better, it has more stuff, it has fewer minor issues, and it's a better port. The level design's worse, but everything else more or less makes up for that. I heartily recommend this game.

31650249.review:
The definitive, must-have version for any Turok 2 fan. Framerate is very consistent and draw distances are greatly enhanced; you will not have to put up with the annoying "fog of war" present in the N64 version.

The good
----------
-PC port of the controls feel pretty intuitive and responsive
-Varied bestiary from the Turok universe (there are actually no human enemies at all in the game)
-Phenomenal soundtrack and satisfying effects really get the adrenaline pumping
-The game ramps up in difficulty on the second stage and even with an asbolute arsenal of crazy guns it still gets progressively tougher right to the end!
-New "hardcore" mode where you only have 1 life to lose: die and it's over
-Lots of secrets and unlockable lore stuff
-Seamless zone transitioning (no load times), quick travel from various in-zone portals allows you to quickly move from stage to stage in ways not possible in the original
-Character and environment models are the best they have ever looked
-Long draw distances make combat more strategic
-Better, more aggressive AI for many mobs
-You can save anytime!
-The flamethrower no longer reduces FPS to 3
-Boss battles are much more fluid at a better frame rate
-Select between the PC and N64 soundtracks (N64 is superior IMO)
-Two words: cerebral bore

The bad
----------
-Unforgiving on higher difficulties
-Hitboxes on some enemies are a bit wonky (smaller enemies can be very annoying and some mobs are deceptively difficult to headshot and/or will take inconsistent damage from weapons with a "spread")
-Some mobs still don't path well to you
-Zones are massive and even with the map can be confusing
-The Lair of the Blind Ones is still absurdly hard
-Game is vast but ends up being more linear than Turok 1
-The Razorwind weapon feels even more quirky to aim than in the original and is mostly useless by the time you get it
-Not a huge amount of replayability
-AI's engagement distance could probably have been tweaked to line up with the increased line of sight of your character (you can really cheese some areas with the Tek bow or Plasma Rifle)


If you can overlook those minor flaws this is a fantastic port of a 90s style console shooter with lots of nice little points of polish to make an old game feel new. The devs have also patched the game several times and they seem receptive to community feedback so it's entirely possible some of the points I mentioned above may get fixed. Nightdive Studios does good work.

8.5 / 10

I loved this game immensely on the N64, and I'm loving it all over again with this release! After playing Turok 1's remaster, I was fully confident in NightDive for Seeds of Evil. It runs so nicely with proper Mouse & Keyboard (no more C-Buttons!), the updated interface is a welcomed touch, and best of all, the lack of fog means I can actually see the world of the game beyond a few meters!
It's enough of a remaster to give it a solid, modern stability & reliability, and plenty has been left untouched to preserve the classic feel of the game. I've been looking forward to this one for a good while, and I'm happy and grateful for the results. NightDive definitely knows how to handle with care.
This has always been an old favorite of mine, due to the exploration of levels, the memorable monster variety, and the plethora of fun weapons! It's because of games like this that made me dislike corridor shooter campaigns where you have 2 or 3 weapons at most. No such limitations for Turok! Where do you keep all those wonderful toys when you don't even have a shirt? Who CARES, it's FUN! That's why these old shooters still hold up.

31215500.review:
------------------------------------------------------

Spiel: 

Ein Klassischer Ego-Shooter der alten Zeit, mit 
Schlüsseln, Geheimissen und Super Gameplay.
Alles Remastered, Optimiert, UNCUT und auf 
Deutsch

------------------------------------------------------

Einzelspieler:

Spielt Turok der die Erde Retten soll, die von Aliens 
die übernommen werden soll.
Die Geschichte ist sehr einfach gehalten aber 
dennoch durch die Zwischensequenzen sehr 
unterhaltsam.

Die Hauptaufgabe ist es verschieden Schlüssel zu
 finden um in die nächsten Level zu kommen. 
In jedem Level gibt es Nebenaufgaben
(die immer gemacht werden müssen) wie Personen
retten, Schalter Aktivieren, bestimmt Gebäude 
zerstören usw., des Weiteren gibt es in jedem 
Level Secrets und Waffenteile für die beste Waffe 
zu finden. 
Das Waffenarsenal ist mit den verschiedensten 
Waffen bestückt und reicht von der Kampfklinge 
bis zum Partikelbeschleuniger, manche Waffen sind 
ganz gut aber manche benutzt man eigentlich nie.

Die Level sind sehr riesig, sehr verwinkelt und haben 
viele verschiedene Ebenen. Jedes Level hat seine 
eigenes Thema was es wirklich sehr 
abwechslungsreich macht, die Gegner ändern sich
je nach Level mit und suchen auch schon mal 
Deckung wenn man auf sie schiesst.

------------------------------------------------------

Mehrspieler:

Der Mehrspieler Modus ist wie Gewohnt vorhanden 
mit vielen (vielen aber nicht allen Maps) aus der 
N64 und PC Version.

Leider wird der Online Modus so gut wie gar nicht
genutzt seit dem Start.

------------------------------------------------------

Grafik:

Die Grafik ist wirklich gut, im Gegensatz zum
damaligen Release auf N64 und PC.

Hohe Weitsicht und kein Nebel mehr vorhanden 
(kann aber wieder zugeschaltet werden).

------------------------------------------------------

Musik:

Die Musik auch wirklich super und sehr passend.
(Es gibt den N64 und PC Version im Spiel zum 
Auswählen.)

Es gibt verschiedene Sprachausgaben u.a. Deutsch,
welche aber bis jetzt nicht besonders klingt.

Ich rate jedem diese überarbeitete Version herunter
zu laden, die sich um Längen besser anhört.
http://steamcommunity.com/app/405830/discussions/1/135512625250156896/

------------------------------------------------------

Steuerung:

Die Steuerung super mit Maus und Tastatur.

------------------------------------------------------

Pro/Contra:

+ Super Gameplay
+ Super Grafik
+ gute Steuerung
+ Super Musik
+ schöne Videos Sequenzen
+ Super Deutsche Synchro
+ gute Boss kämpfe
+ Entwickler arbeiten super mit der Community 
zusammen
- Level manchmal etwas zu unübersichtlich
- zum Schluss wird das Spielt durch Sucher der 
Masters Keys unnötig in die Länge gezogen
- Multiplayer kaum bis garnicht besucht


------------------------------------------------------

Fazit:

Ein wirklich sehr gutes Spiel, kein Vergleich zu 
Turok 1 was ja viele nicht so gut fanden. 
Es ist wirklich schon was anders als Turok 1, 
einfach mehr von allem, Story, Aufgaben, Waffen, 
Gegner Zwischensequenzen. 

Die Grafik ist sicherlich etwas schöner als der 
Original PC Version (was man sich in viele YouTube

31182072.review:
Great remaster of an old school shooter and adventure game.

Turok 2 Seeds of Evil is the sequel to Turok Dinosaur Hunter. This was originally released on the N64 and PC in 1998. Night Dive studios have done a terrific job of remastering the game to run on modern PCs with a bevy of graphical options to tailor the experience. The best of these is the option to remove the fog which is absolutely vital in game which revolves around shooting all manner of dinosaurs/creatures in fairly labyrinthian levels. 

Make no mistake while this is fun no nonsense shooter, it is an adventure game at heart requiring you work through the maze-like levels, collecting keys, pulling levers, find parts for the ultimate weapon with a dose of backtracking for collection of certain artifacts. Use of the automap and keeping your bearings is vital. 

There are also great weapons which feel and sound punchy. Some nice death animations and gore.

Good
+ Great old school shooter
+ Fantastic selection of weapons which look and sound great
+ The cerebral bore - no explanation needed!
+ Great array of graphical options and effects available
+ Non-existent load times
+ Satisfying adventure

Bad
- Getting lost

Overall, a fun shooter/adventure game which is well worth your time.
