30544738.review:
Ещё один ремастер отличной игры от Nightdive Studios. На этот раз - вторая часть культовой игры для Nintendo 64 - Turok 2: Seeds Of Evil. Про саму игру можно много писать, но пройдусь только по основным достоинствам ремастера.
В наличии: улучшенная (частично) графика, новые спецэффекты, улучшенное освещение, доработанные уровни, перерисованные шрифты (но всё в духе оригинала), много настроек, полная совместимость с современными ОС, саундтрек аж в двух вариантах (с Nintendo 64 и с PC)... Нет, даже тут можно много написать.
Проще говоря - просто купите и поиграйте. Стоит ли игра такой суммы? Определённо, да.
P.S. Обладателям первой части - скидка. Лично у меня отображалась только при оплате, впрочем купил я игру сразу как она вышла, поэтому, возможно, просто стим ещё не установил скидку :)

30544517.review:
Video Review Here:
https://youtu.be/UKlVh51ZosM

Transcript:

It’s been nearly 20 years. The late 90’s was an era where First Person Shooters began to break away from the PC space, and comfortably on to consoles. Heavy hitters like Goldeneye 64 and Halo: Combat Evolved, proved that shooters didn’t have to be cumbersome or difficult to play on those platforms. But before all of that, One franchise lead the way for the birth of the console shooter.

Turok Dinosaur Hunter was released on the Nintendo 64 in March of 1997, seven months after the console hit the market. It proved that you didn’t need a keyboard and mouse to enjoy a shooter on a different platform. Turok was released to good critical reception, and was an instant classic. And More than a year later, a successor was released. Nearly two decades have passed, Three Console generations have come and gone, and it’s time to take a Nostalgic trip. And not only has the original Turok: Dinosaur Hunter been remastered with help of modern bells and whistles, Turok 2: Seeds of Evil also got the same treatment. 

Has Night Dive Studios done this iconic and classic franchise the justice is so very needs after two decades? Or is it best left to Oblivion…

STORY-

Set some time after the events of Turok: Dinosaur Hunter- You fill the role of Joshua Fireseed. Summoned by the mysterious alien: Adon, and the Lazarus Concordance- You are asked to fight against the evil Primogen: A powerful alien entity trapped in it’s own Lightship by the Lazarus, in an effort to prevent the destruction of the Universe. The Primogen’s captivity relies on Energy Totems located across the “Lost Land”, and they’re under attack by several primitive species that the Primogen has recruited to destroy them- Freeing him from his Prison. Each Primitive Species has a backstory, or a reason why the Primogen uses them selfishly to fulfill his mission at being free from his captivity

The story does a decent job of laying itself out to you in the very beginning, and at the start of each mission, but doesn’t get in your face when the gameplay sets in.There is a healthy balance of exposition and gameplay that simply works for the game, while keeping the focus primarily on moment-to-moment combat and exploration.

GAMEPLAY-

For a franchise that helped pioneer First Person Shooters on consoles, it certainly does great on PC again. The original version was released on PC, but no where near this quality. 

What could certainly be gleefully jarring is the level design, with environments that are mostly non-linear, which fosters exploration, and maybe even a sense of being lost sometimes. It’s refreshingly and reflective of great game design of the old days when shooter campaigns didn’t travel in a straight line. 

Controls are refined, precise, and enjoyable, with decent options to help tweak to your needs, which is always nice. There’s a satisfying feeling you get from even the simple gun mechanics. The pistol feels punchy, The Mag 60 delivers punishing damage to simpler enemies, and dispatches quickly, and the brutal impact of the shotguns feel just right up close.

And yes.. The wonderful Cerebral Bore is just as amazing as you remembered it.

DESIGN-

Fans of the original will be happy to know that, for better or worse, the game’s base models remain the same. But most exciting is the addition of various graphical enhancements that have been added. Notably is the inclusion per-object motion blur applied to all moving objects, and object shadows.

For those that love graphics options, there’s quite a healthy amount of tuning options, but what’s most pleasing is how well optimized the game is. My i5 3570K and 1070 GPU combination did well to run the game at 4K and at 60 frames per second. 

I would have loved to see some better texture options for the game, as things are still a bit blurry, but overall, this is still the classic experience you remember with a modern glow.

CLOSING-

The Turok Franchise was a glorious staple in the early Nintendo 64 era. Though It’s subsequent sequels didn't get as much praise, which is unfortunate. Night Dive has done a wonderful thing in bringing the originals up from the depths to show them the respect they deserve. It’s character models and textures may have not aged very well, but Turok 2 is certainly worth your time and money, and people who have never had the opportunity certainly owe it to themselves to experience the beginning of the explosive growth of shooters on consoles, when it was the most fun.

30544409.review:
*Received the game for free*

when i think back to my childhood, My mind instantly goes back to what i consider to be my nostalgia days.

Games like DOOM, Timesplitters Duke Nukem, basically raised me as a young lad.

But if theres a game that i have a raging hard on for other than doom, its Turok 2 Seeds Of Evil a game that for the longest time was nearly impossible for me to get my hands on.

After legally obtaining it and totally not torrenting it, the original pc port was finally mine and it was time to kick some a$$.

At least thats what i thought, until the port handed my ass on a plater with low framerates, the game speeding up whenever my framerate increased and constant crashes.

It was like a hot chick rubbing your beef sausage and leaving the room, it left me with blue balls, my balls needed rubbing and it needed rubbing badly.

And now they've finally been rubbed, more than 6 years down the road when Turok 2 Seeds Of Evil has finally been remastered by night dive studios.

And after having the privilege of meeting the team and playing the remasters earliest stages of the development As a Turok fan, i cant think of any reason for fans not to get this.

First off you have quite a few graphics settings for you to tinker with like Motion Blur, Super Sampling, Ambient Occlusion as well as a Field Of View slider and the removal of fog.

You can choose to listen to either the Nintendo 64 soundtrack or PC Soundtrack as well and to have the classic weapon bob or role with the much smoother PC version.

Joshua can now grappel up surfaces allowing for much better traversial of maps and You have an option to have objectives appear on your screen as an exclamation mark to avoid confusion.

If you feel like a challenge there's a new difficulty called hardcore which gives you only one life to beat the game, good luck.

There's now an optional objective marker so if you get lost, you can find the objective much easier when approching it.

The Multiplayer is up and running with Online Play and 4 player Local Split Screen so those of you who played Turok 2 multiplayer all those years ago can fuck people up

You can now quicksave anywhere in the level thank Phuck, as well as Teleport between Warp Portals around the game for easier backtracking which makes collecting keys much easier.

One of the original scrapped Raptor enemies have been fished out and placed back into the game.

There is now a library of sorts that shows all the enemies and weapons you've encountered in the game as well how many shot's you've fired with each weapon all of this plus numerous bug fixes.

But overall for $20 you're getting one of the best remasters we've seen and Nightdive have once again done gods work and given us one of gamings finest. 

Fingers crossed oblivion will be at hand in the next year or so.

39399370.review: An excellent remastering of one of the greatest games of my childhood. They fix many of the flaws that existed in the old N64 version and alowed you to actually use the checkpoints for something. I cannot recommend this game enough.

39327183.review:
I bought this and the first game on sale during the Christmas sale - I was on the fence about whether or not they would hold up or just be a moments worth of nostalgia and then relegated to the dusty section of unplayed older games I have purchased on Steam.

Surprisingly - like the other games Nightdive have re-released, this is still a very good game. It is better than I remember it and I plan on beating it. 

I remember getting this when it came out for Christmas when I was 11. I wanted to like it - but we didn't have a save pack and the game ran slow (had a terrible frame rate). So I'd play it with cheats and just shoot stuff - but Turok is pretty boring when you don't know (care) what you are doing. Then I got my own 2nd hand computer (a 486 with 16mb ram) and kind of stopped playing consoles after really sinking my teeth into classics like System Shock.

But I always had a memory of Turok and Turok 2 - especially the first level in the 2nd game, it just seemed so advanced in my memory.

Playing this now - I am surprised of how much of a good game there is still here. Honestly with a decent frame rate this game just feels great - the shooting is fast and arcadey, and with a proper controller or a mouse-keyboard setup it just feels right.

Graphically the stock game is very nice - I am running with all the enhancements at the highest quality and reshade 3.0 for further graphical tweaking. The texture resolution does not seem to be improved - but the textures themselves are good for the time, even if they do have that blotchy nineties look to them from time to time. Using reshade sharpening and a slightly adjusted cartoon preset helps (in my opinion) by giving the textures a bit of definition and the game a more cel-shaded presentation. The gore is cartoonish - but just as shocking as I remember it. 

The soundtrack is as brilliant as I remember - if a little repetitive. The actual sound of it and the orchestration choices are perfect to provide an epic theme to the action.

I'd say it is worth the asking price if you are a fan of the game from back in the day and just have to play it right now. If you were old enough to have played it at released and still love old games - but did not play it at release, it is worth checking out especially due to the loving restoration work done by Nightdive but I might recommend waiting for a sale if your games budget is not astronomical.

If you were not old enough to have remembered this game coming out and don't have much experience with older first person shooters - this is a fun game, but it is also quite a bit different from modern games. Even with the objective markers and other enhancements in this remaster - this game is essentially a maze with fast paced arcade style shooting that can be punishingly hard on higher difficulties. 

It is kind of like Doom(4) - but with even less emphasis on story, and more sprawling level design. It still looks good - but due to the texture work this still looks like a game from 1998 even with all the fancy features turned on, it is very smooth and the details are economical. Unlike indie games that emulate this style but with almost two decades worth of advancement in design - this is a game where the gameplay principles are dated to 1998. If you can reconcile that - and are interested, it is a very fun action fps game that I would recommend full price if you need a game right now, or on sale if you aren't sure.

39321072.review:
Tras completar no hace mucho el reciente remaster del primer Turok, me lancé a por la segunda entrega en esta vorágine de nostalgia que a veces nos invade a los que ya llevamos unos cuandos años en esto de los videojuegos ^^. Turok 2: Seeds of Evil no es un título que me coja de primeras en estos días, ya que jugué en su día a su versión de N64 y aún conservo una copia de aquel mítico cartucho, pero creo que la plataforma de Nintendo hace mucho que dejó de ser la más ideal para experimentar un FPS y casi 20 años después del lanzamiento original, así que este Remaster venía que ni pintado para volver al que considero una de las grandes joyas del género.

Turok 2 nos sitúa en otro tiempo después de los acontecimientos de la primera entrega, en el pellejo de un nuevo Turok de nombre Joseph Fireseed. En esta ocasión se le encomendará la misión de detener al Primagen, un ser de aspecto extraterrestre que amenaza todo Lost Land, y que por medio de sus tropas o convenciendo a otras razas, atacará los poblados y las tierras habitadas por los humanos con el fin de destruir los Totems Energéticos que pueden destruirle y salir de su cautiverio. Para ello tendremos que recorrer 6 laberínticos niveles cumpliendo una serie de misiones y avanzando a través de las fuerzas del Primagen para derrotarle.

Este juego presenta una buena serie de diferencias respecto a su antecesor. La primera y una de las más notorias es la cantidad de objetivos que tendremos que cumplir y que, en algunos casos, incluso comprenderá una serie de implicaciones jugables que le destacan de la mayoría de juegos del género. Cada nivel tiene una serie de misiones propias que tendremos que cumplir antes de abandonarlo, desde rescatar a niños o soldados cautivos, hasta destruir depósitos de armas u otros objetivos. Implícitamente, aunque no lo recalquen al empezar los niveles, también tendremos que encontrar items imprescindibles para avanzar, como las llaves de niveles que ya estaban presentes en el primer Turok, las llaves Primagen para el jefe final, o las pumas que, llevadas a sus altares, otorgan poderes especiales. Estos poderes serán imprescindibles para alcanzar algunos objetos además de descubrir rutas y secretos alternativos, y añadirá un elemento de backtracking al juego, algo no muy común en el género. 

Para conseguir todo esto, tendremos que movernos por cada uno de los niveles buscando en todos los recovecos, incluso volviendo sobre nuestros pasos, lo que hace de Turok 2 una experiencia que va mucho más allá de disparar y avanzar. El diseño de escenarios es simplemente una locura. Largos, complejos, retorcidos..., el sentido de la orientación será vital en muchas ocasiones, y estaremos obligados a usar el mapa más de una vez, sobre todo en escenarios que plantean túneles y pasillos de similar apariencia y que complicarán todo. En esta ocasión, Seeds of Evil renuncia al estilo selvático del primer juego para ambientar la acción en escenarios más lúgubres y decadentes. Niveles como Port of Adia o River of Souls se ambientan en zonas moderadamente urbanizadas, con Death Marshes y Lair of the Blind Ones siendo los más oscuros en un entramado de pantanos y túneles subterraneos, con Hive of the Mantids poniendo la nota más "extraterrestre", y Primagen Lightning el punto tecnológico en una enorme nave. Tecniicamente Turok 2 mantiene más alto el tipo en comparación con la primera entrega, tanto en el plano visual como, y sobre todo, en el aspecto sonoro, con contundentes efectos y una banda sonora que tanto en composición como en calidad encumbra la obra.

Pero sin duda una de las notas más destacables desde siempre fue su arsenal. Si la primera entrega contaba con armas de todo tipo y era muy completo en ese sentido, Turok 2 eleva el listón y lo sitúa donde pocos llegan a nivel creativo. A algunar armas clásicas como la pistola, la escopeta, o el mítico arco Tek, se le suman nuevas adiciones como el rifle voltáico, el Nuke (que tendremos que conseguir juntando sus partes), la Razor Wind o el mítico Cerebral Bore, un taladro teledirigido que se clava y trepana los craneos de los enemigos para finalizar con una explosión, instakill garantizado. No solo hay creatividad, sino también cantidad, más de una veintena y que podremos llevar y usar cuando queramos, Old School del bueno, que sumado a la intensa violencia del juego, con decapitaciones, desmembramientos y otros efectos, queda con un conjunto de lo más atractivo para los amantes de la acción sin restricciones.

Con todo, este Remaster cuenta con algunos añadidos y modificaciones. Por supuesto las opciones gráficas y muchas otras inclusiones técnicas han sido implementadas para actualizar este clásico, pero también se han establecido cambios notables que infieren en la jugabilidad, como la posibilidad de activar una ayuda que nos indique la ubicaciones de los objetivos, algo que agradecerán los que no quieran matarse a buscar frustrados (y los que no quieran ayudas, siempre pueden desactivarlo), y también se han rediseñado algunas partes de los niveles, sobre todos aquellos encarados antiguamente a transiciones, y la ubicación de algunos objetos se ha modificado. En general, el remaster pule algunas aristas y actualiza el juego a nivel técnico, pero no esperéis algo como un remake, porque el aspecto sigue conservándose íntegro. También sigue estando el multiplayer, aunque no sé a día de hoy qué interés podrá despertar.


A veces se ha tildado a Turok 2 como el metroidvania de los FPS, o incluso el Dark Souls de los shooters. La segunda afirmación no me parece muy próxima, salvando la dificultad que puede llegar a ser muy alta, pero la primera no tanto, si tenemos en cuenta que muchos miembros de Iguana Entertainment formaron después Retro Studios, y ya sabéis qué crearon aquellos chicos. Puede que, al fin y al cabo, Turok 2 fuese el prototipo que gestó una de las obras maestras de lo que sería la next gen de Nintendo tras N64, pero para su época, Turok 2 fue también un impactante título, no del agrado de todos por su dificultad, sus desquiciantes niveles y toda la complejidad que comportaba, pero al mismo tiempo fue un título que se desmarcó absolutamente de toda la saga y, en mi opinión, fue el pico nunca superado de la franquicia, con un estilo que no se ha imitado apenas. Si queréis un reto desafiante, y no os echáis para atrás con unos niveles enormes e intimidantes, esta sigue siendo una obra imprescindible. Si quieres algo más complejo en ese sentido, creo que ya tienes que ir mirando hacia System Shock.

Si quieres unirte a mi grupo: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/JoshCell

Si quieres seguirme como mentor: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/29569915-Josh-Cell/

39280175.review:
I first played Turok 2 on the N64 back in 1998. I was a young teen gamer back then, full of hormone-fuelled anger, wearing all-black clothing and with no patience whatsoever! So of course I never completed the game (there was no name for 'rage-quit' back then!) although I do remember thinking how atmospheric it was and how cool the weapons were. Somehow those thoughts must have stayed with me when I saw this new remake on Steam.

So having completed this game (hey, it only took 20 years!) how do I sum it up for other potential players? I'm going to try and review it for both people who played the original and those completely new to it. I need to say to those new to it that you may not get much out of it - this is a 20 year old game made up of polygons and textures which can't come close to anything around today. Having said that, given how old this game is you may be surprised by how well the gameplay holds up, how the music and atmosphere sticks in your head and how challenging the game can be.

The start of the game sets the tone for [i]almost[/i] everything to follow: you play from the first-person perpective of Turok (a title meaning 'Son Of Stone' according to the Turok comics). You start the game having appeared through a portal into a kind of Xen/outer space dimenision and meet an alien who introduces herself as Adon, the Speaker of Forever Light. Adon explains that you need to stop a creature called the Primagen from destroying five energy totems which keep him a prisoner in his Lightship, otherwise his blast of temporal energy will destroy the universe - no pressure! Promptly she sends you to the game's first level, the Port Of Aida. She gives you a little background to the location, explains what you need to do and what you're up against -the Dinosoid army, a race of gentically engineered dinosaur hybrids. She'll repeat the format of these speeches for every level you find throughout the game, although each level has it's own specific objectives. After that, it's huntin' time!

So let's get going with the core of the game, an FPS adventure filled with a host of enemies, locations, objectives and more. The game's biggest strength is in the uniqueness and variety of what it throws at you: just as you get used to one weapon (a pistol) the game has another, completely different weapon around the corner (a bow) followed by melee weapons, a harpoon gun, a shotgun, a charge-dart rifle... and so on. You might be thinking that these weapons are common to other FPS games, and you're not wrong, but with these regular weapons the game also gives you different types of ammo: a shotgun can be used with explosive pellets, bows can be used with explosive arrows and can be upgraded to the Tek Bow which has a sniper sight, and so on. Even the basic pistol feels punchy and fun, and this is all before you get to the truly unique, most memorable weapons of the game. If you've never heard of the Cerebal Bore before... trust me, nobody forgets their first time.

This variety extends to the game's enemies too: just as you get used to a dinosoid that peppers you with plasma gunfire from behind a crate, the game will throw up another that swiftly charges you from a distance, followed by herds of tiny dinosaurs that move too quickly to shoot and swarm around you, tearing at your feet. Later there are insectoids, zombies, mammalians, spiders, cave-dwellers, worms, robotic hybrids and more, each with their own characteristics and methods. The levels of the game will also change to serve as platforms and environments for this army of monsters, changing music and mood very effectively as you progress.

One of the things that always divided opinion about the game is the level design. I've played my fair share of modern and old FPS shooters where the player is encouraged to explore and work out where to go, but the later levels of this game almost confused the hell out of me! It's very easy to miss an objective or even the path/portal that leads to it (like missing that one small key in the Water Temple of Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time). I'm not sure if this is intentional or not, but it's certainly effective if you like a challenge. Using the map is essential, and it can be difficult to know if you've looked around every corner. There's no avoiding backtracking either because of the power-ups you'll need to collect before you can reach cetain areas, although in these areas there's usually a portal nearby - if you can remember which one! The game respawns a few enemies when you revisit but the majority will be gone if you've taken care of them. The game's levels certainly make great use of their 3D space, with many twisting and turning paths or buildings/areas you'll be unable to visit until later on. If you see a path far above you and haven't walked on it by the time the level ends, it can certainly feel disheartening when the game tells you you've missed an objective - there are a few times where finding that missing route takes work.

The music in the game is very good, even for a 20 year old game. You may find yourself humming the themes you'll hear and each level's music is well suited. In the remake you have a choice between the N64 and PC versions too. My only complaint is that the music can overwhelm the speech - even if you turn it down to 75% of the speech volume Adon's mission briefings can be difficult to understand without subtitles. This may also be down to the choice of using what sounds like the original voice recordings, they sound like they have a very low bitrate/quality. (This could be down to my headphones too, I've seen gameplay videos on YouTube which don't have this problem at all.)

Finally, I need to heap a ton of praise on Nightdive Studios for the job they've done with this game. I ran the game maxed out on a 4K monitor and was impressed at how the core of the game is untouched and yet enchanced at the same time. There are a lot of graphics options, sound options and gameplay options, the most notable being the option to highlight switches and buttons plus the ability to jump between portals.

So overall, should you buy this game if you have or haven't played the original? 

If you've never played the original, don't expect anything near the standard of modern games. I would play if you appreciate the classics and you like a bit of a challenge, you may find a lot of appreciation for the game's atmosphere and it's unique moments along the way. This was a high review-scoring classic back in the day and it has characteristics that are as memorable now as they were 20 years ago.

If you have played the original and have fond memories of it... just buy it!

39092615.review:
I've been a long time Turok fan, playing this game in N64 days as a child, so when I saw this game was remastered, I HAD to buy it. And upon playing already for about 5-6 hours total, I'm not dissapointed! This is the smoothest this game has EVER played, especially on PC. And surprisingly, after playing this game for YEARS on N64, I enjoy this port the most, and actually enjoy playing keyboard/ mouse so much more on this port. The keyboard/ mouse chemistry this game has is marvelous. 
Now, here are some pro's and con's just generally about the game:
PROS:
-A truly unique and different setting, the worlds and atmospheres in this game are incredible, even for today's standards. 
-The gameplay, while it is your run-of-the-mill, first person shooter, and could be compared to the likes of Goldeneye or Quake, is VERY fluent, and as I highlighted earlier, keyboard and mouse feel incredible in this game. It'd feel foreign playing any other way. And that's coming from an N64 fan who spent hours upon hours playing this on the N64. 
- The enemies are unique, and very original. Everything from the dinosaurs to the bug-like aliens you face towards the end of the game. 
- The weapons may be the most unique weapons offered in a game. Everything from the Shredder to the infamous Cerebal Bore. They're definitely an aresenal to expereince. 
- The soundtrack is one of the best soundtracks coming from an FPS, maybe a game in general. 
- You will get your money's worth, and spend hours upon hours in the Turok world. Even if you think you've uncovered everything on the levels, you most likely haven't. There's also an online section, which admittedly, I haven't spent much time on. I did conntect to a dedicated server, but no players were actually on. Turok online may be dead already, but to me, it's no big deal, considering I bought this for the story mode. 
- The missions, and alert signs make finding everything ten times easier, and cuts back on the frusturation the orinal port had to offer. 
- QUICKSAVE....do I have to say more? 

CONS:
- The levels can get very frusutrating, and can have a labrynth-type-feel to them, especially 'River of Souls'. It's easy to get lost, and to find items or things you might need to complete a level, and it's very easy to even completely miss a section. 
- I've found that the smaller enemies in the game (i.e spiders, small dinosaurs, worms, etc) are the most annoying, often hard to kill with weapons. This is probably the reason they're implemented, but it can make things a little fursturating. Using the claws is your best bet for these types of enemies. 
- Non-skippable cutscenes, not the hugest of deals, but to some, this may be annoying. If you enter the cheat though, cutscenes are skippable. 

All in all, Turok 2:Seed of Evil remastered is an EXCELLENT game WORTH the 20 USD price tag. I'm very impressed with how Night Dive Studios tweaked and perfected this game! Bravo!

39038252.review:
Yep, it's Turok 2.  This is an old Nintendo 64 game from the 90's.  They've updated it to work on modern computers, and added a few nice little touches.

The only gripes I have about the game itself are the same gripes I had with the original:  There's not many actual dinosaurs in this game.  There's velociraptors and a triceratops (that you ride!), and fans of Jurassic Park will definitely notice the Compys (Compsognathus) but I'm pretty sure that's it.  The rest of the baddies are human-dinosaur hybrids, aliens, mutants, cyborgs, zombies, and some demon things thrown in for good measure.

Still a great game though.  It's hard as all get-out and the levels are excrutiatingly long.  These could be modern day complaints.  But for me, they are not.

The music is absolutely gripping too, by the way.

39416290.review:
Such an incredible throwback to when my reflexes were sharper and my tolerance for bad framerates was higher than it should have. However, with quicksaves and MUCH smoother and cleaner graphics than the source material, I can finally enjoy this game in present day - no Expansion or Controller Paks required!

I've only played a bit into the first level of single-player, and it's holding up pretty well on my hunk-of-junk Lappy 486. You don't seem to need much to run this at a decent clip, and the visuals are (intentionally?) not much better than on the N64's "Hi-Rez" mode. Mouse and keyboard controls make lining headshots a joke, so I can blitz through tricky spots without having to rely on farming the regenerating health and ammo caches.

Protip: Use the talon claw as much as possible early on. Bait a melee attack, dodge backwards by a step or two, and then move into the enemy as they finish their animation with a well-timed swipe to the noggin for maximum damage.

I can't wait to see how the later levels look, and if I can even run them acceptably well on this laptop. As long as I can still use the charge dart rifle / war blade combo, I'm fine.

This is worth checking out. Maybe wait for a sale if you're not a nostalgia junkie like me, but you could do worse. It's a linear FPS adventure with a fair bit of backtracking for power-ups and there are secrets all over the place.
